subject: Re: [junit] Testing Abstract Classes
msgSnippet: ... If that s what an Adapter is, then what is a Bridge? I don t have my copy of Design Patterns handy right now. What you describe is what I would call a
messageBody:
teemu kanstren wrote:

> I guess that definition is in line with the default Adapter classes provided
> in the JDK. I always rather think of an Adapter as a component that converts
> the interface of a component to match the interface of another, as I think
> it is defined in the GoF book. Don't know what does that have to do with an
> empty strategy, or what is an empty strategy though. But I'm sure we will
> soon know :).

If that's what an Adapter is, then what is a Bridge? I don't have my
copy of Design Patterns handy right now. What you describe is what I
would call a Bridge.
--
J. B. (Joe) Rainsberger :: http://www.jbrains.info
Your guide to software craftsmanship
JUnit Recipes: Practical Methods for Programmer Testing
2005 Gordon Pask Award for contribution Agile Software Practice
